title: Song of Deliverance
shortSummary: Exodus 15 celebrates God's mighty deliverance of Israel from Egyptian bondage through the miraculous crossing of the Red Sea. The chapter features a triumphant song of praise led by Moses and Miriam, followed by God's provision and guidance in the wilderness. It highlights God's power, faithfulness, and covenantal care for His people.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Exodus and the Red Sea Crossing

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel who leads the people out of Egypt and sings a song of praise to God for their deliverance.

keyCharacters.name: Miriam
keyCharacters.description: Sister of Moses and Aaron, a prophetess who leads the women in worship and celebration after the crossing of the Red Sea.

keyCharacters.name: Pharaoh
keyCharacters.description: The Egyptian ruler whose army is destroyed in the Red Sea while pursuing Israel.

definitions.definition: A small hand drum or tambourine used in ancient Israelite worship and celebration.
Laws and commandments given by God to guide the moral and religious life of His people.
A place name meaning 'bitter,' referring to the bitter water that the Israelites encountered in the wilderness.
The sacred place where God dwells, often referring to the tabernacle or temple.

outline.heading: The Song of Moses and Israel's Praise
outline.description: Moses and the Israelites sing a powerful song of praise to the LORD for His victorious deliverance over Pharaoh's army, celebrating God's strength, holiness, and protection.

outline.heading: Miriam's Leadership in Worship
outline.description: Miriam, the prophetess, leads the women in joyful worship with timbrels and dancing, echoing the song of triumph over the defeated Egyptians.

outline.heading: Journey into the Wilderness and Bitter Water at Marah
outline.description: The Israelites travel three days into the wilderness without water, then find bitter water at Marah, which causes them to complain to Moses.

outline.heading: God's Provision and Covenant Promise
outline.description: God instructs Moses to make the bitter water sweet by casting a tree into it, establishing a statute and promising healing and protection if Israel obeys His commandments.

outline.heading: Encampment at Elim
outline.description: The chapter concludes with Israel arriving at Elim, a place of abundant water and shade, where they rest and prepare for the journey ahead.

application: Praise God for His mighty deliverance in your life, recognizing His power to overcome any enemy or obstacle.
Trust in God's provision during difficult seasons, remembering that He can turn bitterness into blessing when we obey Him.
Follow the example of Miriam by leading others in worship and rejoicing in God's faithfulness.
Commit to obeying God's statutes and commandments as a pathway to experiencing His healing and protection.

keyVerses.text: The LORD is my strength and song, and he is become my salvation: he is my God, and I will prepare him an habitation; my father's God, and I will exalt him.
keyVerses.significance: This verse expresses personal trust and commitment to God as Savior and strength, foundational for faithful worship.

keyVerses.text: Who is like unto thee, O LORD, among the gods? who is like thee, glorious in holiness, fearful in praises, doing wonders?
keyVerses.significance: It highlights God's uniqueness, holiness, and mighty works, inspiring awe and reverence.

keyVerses.text: And said, If thou wilt diligently hearken to the voice of the LORD thy God, and wilt do that which is right in his sight, and wilt give ear to his commandments, and keep all his statutes, I will put none of these diseases upon thee, which I have brought upon the Egyptians: for I am the LORD that healeth thee.
keyVerses.significance: God's covenant promise linking obedience to protection and healing, encouraging faithful living.

keyVerses.text: And Miriam answered them, Sing ye to the LORD, for he hath triumphed gloriously; the horse and his rider hath he thrown into the sea.
keyVerses.significance: Miriam's call to worship celebrates God's glorious victory and encourages communal praise.
